channel.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
channel.description:
So, I was desperate just to wipe everything off my computer, and freshly install Windows XP on it.
I currently HAD Windows XP and Ubuntu.
Simple enough, right?
[b]NO.[/b]
Nothing seemed to work -- Formatting, formatting from command prompt, XP cd.
I was desperate for ANYTHING, and deleted the Linux partion [forgot how and don't ask why I did, nub move], restarted computer, Grub 17 error. Great.
Now I'm stuck here. The only thing that seems to work is CTRL+ALT+DEL. Which restarts the computer.
What I've tried: Booting from three different windows XP CD's. Booting from Ubuntu LiveCD. Ultimate Boot CD.
By the way, when both operating systems worked at the time, I did NOT have my WinXP CDs.
Other information;
I've tried booting from the BIOS, but it can't seem to find the CD for a boot option. I can't access my BIOS settings because; A. When I press F1 at startup it asks for a password that I don't know, or don't remember setting. B. I just can't seem to find it. I don't know what BIOS company I have.
This is all I can remember for now, any help?

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I’m sure you don’t have OS/2, my bet is that it is your ‘recovery partition’.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @Divine-Devil Divine-Devil
item.description:
@Divine-Devil wrote:

Lol, no this is my computer.

I have an HP pavilion Slimeline, o.O.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @adamp40 adamp40
item.description:
@adamp40 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:23, topic:255205”]Wtf, OS/2?

Uh, is this your dads pc or something? Because if so he might be fairly pissed off with you if you just wiped out his OS/2 partition.[/quote]
Lol thats some really Old Operating System.

Its only 7gb so why worry about it.- If you have a some ancient 20gb HD (which you probably do becuase theres OS/2 installed) then you should.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Wtf, OS/2?

Uh, is this your dads pc or something? Because if so he might be fairly pissed off with you if you just wiped out his OS/2 partition.

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @Divine-Devil Divine-Devil
item.description:
@Divine-Devil wrote:

Got it working.

;).

Thanks guys.

BTW, do any of you guys know what ’ J: Partion3 <Inactive <OS/2 Boot Man 7461 MB < 450 MB free > ’ means, should I delete it?

I’m on the Windows XP installation.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

It may well be soldered on btw, so why not just use the jumper

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

It almost looks like a coin, on your motherboard.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @Divine-Devil Divine-Devil
item.description:
@Divine-Devil wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:18, topic:255205”][quote author=jme link=topic=337243.msg2619579#msg2619579 date=1231282468]

It doesn’t find the disk, it should find the CD drive. If the boot menu doesn’t show the CD drive, you have to get into the BIOS. If the BIOS has a password, then you need to reset it on the motherboard with the BIOS reset jumper. You will need to read the model number off the mobo and google to find out where the jumper is.

You can also remove the CMOS battery. I did this when I was a noob as it was easier then finding the jumper. Can’t remember if you have to leave it out for a while though.
[/quote]In and out as long as the computer is off.[/quote]

I heard that too, and not sure where to go from there, I never actually opened up my computer, so I’m no genius on that subject.

I’ll try to google it, but do you guys know a legit site, that won’t try tricking a nub like me into doing something stupid?

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:17, topic:255205”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=337243.msg2619546#msg2619546 date=1231280313]
It doesn’t find the disk, it should find the CD drive. If the boot menu doesn’t show the CD drive, you have to get into the BIOS. If the BIOS has a password, then you need to reset it on the motherboard with the BIOS reset jumper. You will need to read the model number off the mobo and google to find out where the jumper is.
[/quote]

You can also remove the CMOS battery. I did this when I was a noob as it was easier then finding the jumper. Can’t remember if you have to leave it out for a while though.[/quote]In and out as long as the computer is off.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Moparisthebest:

It doesn’t find the disk, it should find the CD drive. If the boot menu doesn’t show the CD drive, you have to get into the BIOS. If the BIOS has a password, then you need to reset it on the motherboard with the BIOS reset jumper. You will need to read the model number off the mobo and google to find out where the jumper is.

You can also remove the CMOS battery. I did this when I was a noob as it was easier then finding the jumper. Can’t remember if you have to leave it out for a while though.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @Divine-Devil Divine-Devil
item.description:
@Divine-Devil wrote:

I know. I’ve been to the booting options screen, but it can’t find the disk.

And I think my BIOS settings has a password, I forgot which option I chose at BIOS but when I do it, it asks for a password, [Black background, white text].
I don’t remember setting one.

The only thing its ever identified was a USB, but it didn’t boot from that either.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Yes, it’s different on every mobo, sometimes F11, ESC or whatever else the BIOS programmer chose.

[quote=“Divine-Devil, post:13, topic:255205”]My bad, my computer starts up, while doing so, it shows BIOS splash screen.
Then it loads grub, and I get error 17.

That’s where I’m stuck.[/quote]

You shouldn’t let it get that far, you need to get into the BIOS config screen or the boot menu first.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @Divine-Devil Divine-Devil
item.description:

My bad, my computer starts up, while doing so, it shows BIOS splash screen.
Then it loads grub, and I get error 17.

That’s where I’m stuck.

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

It’s not always f8…

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

when your computer boots, usually the bios has a splash picture it displays, start tapping f8 multiple times until you can access the boot order, then do this:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:2, topic:255205”]So, a CD does not boot?

If it does boot, go into the XP one and press R for repair mode. Then type fixmbr and press Y.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Divine-Devil, post:9, topic:255205”]It just won’t boot at all. From CD, or normally.

It just shows one option in boot options [BIOS I guess?] and when I click that, its just an endless cycle of fail.[/quote]

You’re doing it wrong.

Try going into the bios options and changing the boot order so that cd is above hard drive, and then booting normally.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You should be able to boot from a CD. If you can’t you are most likely doing it wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

open the case and remove the BIOS battery for 10 secs, then close the case and plug everything back in. Turn on and enter BIOS.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

To change the boot order you don’t need a pass IIRC.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @adamp40 adamp40
item.description:
@adamp40 wrote:

Your Bios should have a order sequence for booting.

But as you dont have the password I dont think its possible to do anything accpet get a new HD.

On the Linux thing doesnt it show part of the grub and let you edit it?

The only way to change password of your BIOS is in a Windows or Linux Enviroment

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

When you press the power button, a screen flashes by saying something about the boot order and other things. Press the corresponding key and set the primary boot to CD. I guess your PC tries to boot from the HD, and succeeds, but then fucks up.

Read full topic

item.title: Wow, screwed up bad, help?
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

So, a CD does not boot?

If it does boot, go into the XP one and press R for repair mode. Then type fixmbr and press Y.

Read full topic
